title: 103_s394
content: Credit for payments or contributions to certain cooperative research organizations. The amendment allows for a 50 percent credit on qualified cooperative research expenditures. Qualified cooperative research expenditures are defined as the total amount of qualified expenses for collaborative research activities. The amendment allows for a 50 percent credit on qualified cooperative research expenditures, which are defined as contributions to research consortia for collaborative research activities. The term 'qualified contributions' refers to contributions to research consortia for research activities, subject to limitations on private source funding. The private source funding ratio is calculated based on the organization's gross receipts, excluding governmental support, for the previous taxable year. It consists of 50% of the organization's gross receipts ratio to total gross receipts, plus an additional 30% of that ratio. The private source funding ratio is calculated based on the organization's gross receipts, excluding governmental support, for the previous taxable year. It includes 50% of the organization's gross receipts ratio to total gross receipts, plus 30% of that ratio for the second preceding taxable year, and 20% for the third preceding taxable year. Contributions representing costs allocated to services performed by a taxpayer's employees exceeding cash contributions are not considered qualified contributions. In determining qualified contributions, costs allocated to services performed by a taxpayer's employees exceeding cash contributions are not considered. Overhead allocated to services performed by employees exceeding 25% of salary and benefits is also excluded. Contributions to a qualified cooperative research consortium exceeding one-third of the consortium's total nongovernmental support are not counted. Contributions to a qualified cooperative research consortium exceeding one-third of the consortium's total nongovernmental support are not counted if the consortium has fewer than 5 participants making nongovernmental contributions. If a qualified cooperative research consortium has less than 5 participants making nongovernmental contributions, the contributions of each person will be reduced by 20% if there are 4 participants, or by 40% if there are 3 participants. A qualified cooperative research consortium is an organization registered under the National Cooperative Research Act of 1984. A qualified cooperative research consortium is an organization registered under the National Cooperative Research Act of 1984, with at least 5 contributors, where no 3 members can contribute more than 80% of total nongovernmental contributions. A qualified cooperative research consortium must have at least 5 contributors, with specific contribution limits to ensure diversity and fair distribution of nongovernmental contributions. For a qualified cooperative research consortium, contributors must adhere to contribution limits to ensure diversity and fair distribution of nongovernmental contributions. Noncash contributions are considered at their cost, and services provided by employees are included. Noncash contributions, including services from taxpayer's employees, are valued at cost. Overhead costs for employee services are included. Contributions for qualified cooperative research expenditures cannot be double-counted. Prepaid contributions to qualified research consortia are allocated to the appropriate research. The subsection on computing qualified cooperative research expenditures excludes certain contributions from being counted. Prepaid amounts for qualified research consortia are treated as paid during the research period. Each consortium must provide a report to the Secretary including certification, funding ratio, and other required information. The consortium must submit a report to the Secretary with certification, funding ratio, and other required information. Each consortium must also provide a copy of the report to each contributor. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of this Act.
